bibl.title: Letter fragment from [Walter Reed] to [Dorsey M. McPherson], [1880?]

div1.p: Reed teases McPherson and writes that he cannot take more leave to be McPherson's best man. Reed will travel to Warrenton, Virginia and to White Sulphur Springs.

div1.head: Letter fragment from [Walter Reed] to [Dorsey M. McPherson], [1880?]
div1.p:
Soup with a “patholog-
ical” roast! “How”? -- “I
desire to be informed”!
Now, my dear boy, listen
to your uncle “Wm T.”
and hearken unto his
words -- viz: if I ever stand
another examination, af-
ter this one, you may
go to my “Banker” and ask
him to turn over to you
all my hard earned gold!
“Sabe”? Speaking of “gold”
admonishes me that you
must be now a perfect
“Croesus”! I don't suppose
you would turn on your
“bloated” heel for a
$10 note! “I want to know”

Concerning being your
“best man” on a certain
occasion, my dear boy, I
think, however, agreeable
to me it would be, that I
will certainly be debarred
from that pleasure- I have
now taken all the leave that
I will be entitled to till after
June 30th 1881, and I know that
it would simply be impossible
to get even one (1) day, this
winter. But I know you
will take “the will for the deed”-
I will leave here very soon
for Warrenton, Va, on a
little pleasure tour- Shall
run over also to the “White
Sulphur-” “How”? Please ask
the C.O. when it is likely that
my baggage will get out
of Arizona. Also ask Mr
Staples wheth-
er he got the
check for $133.00
which I for-
warded to him
a month ago.
Don't forget
this- I hope
Dr McC. got
the tin pans,
“Counterpane”,
& “Woodward's
Steward's man-
-ual”- As I
got the ” salt
cellar before
I left & the
two(2)
“pillow-
-slips,”
I only owe
him one
“night-cap”,
will send
it, as soon
as I can
get one.
Write me
at “War-
renton,
Va, just
as soon
as you
get this.
Give my
very
